metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of survey at the poplar sampling plot at Linze station foci experimental area (2008.06)
metadata.description:
The dataset of survey at the poplar sampling plot was obtained in the Linze station foci experimental area.
     Observation items included:
     (1) soil profile moisture and temperature (0-5cm, 0-5cm, 10-20cm, 20-40cm and 40-60cm) with photos measured twice by the cutting ring method (50cm^3, each layer), once by ML2X Soil Moisture Tachometer and the probe thermometer (15cm, twice each layer) on Jun. 3, 2008. Data were archived as Excel files.
    (2) shallow layer soil moisture (0-5cm) measured once by the cutting ring method (50cm^3, once each point) and twice by ML2X Soil Moisture Tachometer on Jun. 4, 2008. 13 points were selected and data were archived as Excel files. 
     (3) LAI by TRAC on Jul. 20, 2008. Data were archived as Excel files.
     (4) roughness measured by the roughness plate together with the digital camera. 18 points were selected and data were archived in JPG format format.
     (5) forest investigation of Populus gansuensis from Jun. 5-13, 2008: coordinates, the diameter at breast height and the crown size by the measuring tape, full height by TruPulse200. 408 trees were selected and data were archived as Excel files.
     See the metadata record “WATER: Dataset of setting of the sampling plots and stripes in the Linze station foci experimental area” for more information of the quadrate locations.

Verification.Question: Is the ML2X soil moisture rapid tester used consistently across different soil layers for moisture measurement in a dataset?

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of soil moisture measurement techniques used in poplar sample plots?
Feature Specification.Answer: ring knife method, ring knife volume of 50 cm^3, ML2X soil moisture rapid tester, duplicate samples, measurements at 0-5 cm, 10-20 cm, 20-40 cm, 40-60 cm, data stored in Excel format

Quantification.Question: How many layers of soil were examined for soil moisture and temperature measurements in the poplar sample plots?

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on data accuracy and consistency when using different instruments and methods, such as the ML2X soil moisture rapid meter and the American 6310 needle soil thermometer, for measuring soil moisture and temperature across varying soil layers?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using different instruments and methods, such as the ML2X soil moisture rapid meter and the American 6310 needle soil thermometer, for measuring soil moisture and temperature across varying soil layers might result in variations in data accuracy and consistency. These variations could be due to differences in instrument sensitivity, calibration, and environmental conditions during data collection. The choice of method and instrument may influence the precision of measurements, and combining data from different tools may require careful calibration and validation to ensure comparability and accuracy.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind conducting comprehensive soil profile investigations and tree surveys in poplar sample plots in remote sensing joint experiments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include understanding the soil moisture and temperature variations at different depths to aid in remote sensing data applications, assessing the forest structure through tree measurements such as diameter, height, and canopy width, and evaluating the surface roughness for enhancing remote sensing models. These objectives support the broader goal of improving the accuracy and applicability of remote sensing techniques in ecological and environmental monitoring.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in measuring soil moisture and temperature across different soil layers in a research study focusing on poplar tree plots?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involve using the ring knife method (with a ring knife volume of 50cm^3) to measure soil moisture, with two repetitions per layer, and the ML2X soil moisture quick test device for one-time measurement per layer. Soil temperature is measured using an American 6310 needle-type soil thermometer (15cm), with two repetitions per layer. The soil layers include 0-5cm, 0-5cm, 10-20cm, 20-40cm, and 40-60cm.
